items.title: 선택을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Expressing choices
items.exampleEn: It’s more accurate to say I was disappointed than angry.
items.description: Refines/corrects a label: 'not so much A as B.'
items.tip: Useful for nuanced feedback or polite disagreement.

generatedExamples.korean: 그 사람은 나를 싫어한다기보다는 그냥 내 성격이 안 맞는 것 같아.
generatedExamples.english: It's not so much that he dislikes me, but rather that our personalities just don't match.

generatedExamples.korean: 이 영화는 재미없다기보다는 오히려 지루하다고 할 수 있어.
generatedExamples.english: It's not so much that this movie is uninteresting, but rather that it's quite boring.

generatedExamples.korean: 이 직장은 힘들다기보다는 도전적이라고 할 수 있어요.
generatedExamples.english: It's not so much that this job is hard, but rather that it's challenging.

generatedExamples.korean: 그 사람은 잘못했다기보다는 상황이 그렇게 만든 것 같아.
generatedExamples.english: It's not so much that he did something wrong, but rather that the situation led him to it.

generatedExamples.korean: 이 요리는 맛없다기보다는 내 입맛에 맞지 않아요.
generatedExamples.english: It's not so much that this dish is tasteless, but rather that it doesn't suit my taste.

items.title: 선택을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Expressing choices
items.example: 늦게 출발할 바에야 안 가는 게 낫죠.
items.tip: Stronger than -느니. It implies that because the first option is so bad, doing the second (often opposite) action is a much better choice.
items.exampleEn: If we’re going to leave late, let’s just leave tomorrow.
items.description: Stronger concession than -느니; if A is that bad, B is distinctly better.

generatedExamples.korean: 이런 음식을 먹을 바에야 그냥 굶는 게 낫겠다.
generatedExamples.english: If I have to eat food like this, it’s better to just starve.

generatedExamples.korean: 그 일에 계속 얽힐 바에야 다른 직장을 찾는 게 나아.
generatedExamples.english: If I have to keep getting involved in that work, it’s better to find another job.

generatedExamples.korean: 그 사람과 계속 다툴 바에야 아예 연락하지 않는 게 좋아.
generatedExamples.english: If I have to keep arguing with that person, it’s better not to contact them at all.

generatedExamples.korean: 이 영화를 볼 바에야 다른 취미를 찾는 게 낫지.
generatedExamples.english: If I have to watch this movie, it’s better to find another hobby.

generatedExamples.korean: 비 오는 날에 나가서 기다릴 바에야 집에서 쉬는 게 좋겠어.
generatedExamples.english: If I have to go out and wait on a rainy day, it’s better to rest at home.

items.title: 선택을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Expressing choices
items.example: 날씨가 덥건 춥건 운동은 해야 해요.
items.tip: Connects two contrasting words to mean "regardless of whether it's A or B." The outcome remains the same.
items.exampleEn: Whether it's hot or cold, you have to exercise.

generatedExamples.korean: 주말에 비가 오건 해가 나건 산책을 할 거예요.
generatedExamples.english: Regardless of whether it rains or the sun shines on the weekend, I will go for a walk.

generatedExamples.korean: 직장에서 일이 많건 적건, 항상 최선을 다해야 해요.
generatedExamples.english: Regardless of whether there is a lot of work or a little at the office, you should always do your best.

generatedExamples.korean: 그 사람과 친해지건 멀어지건, 내 결정은 변하지 않을 거야.
generatedExamples.english: Regardless of whether I get closer to that person or grow distant, my decision will not change.

generatedExamples.korean: 음악을 듣건 영화를 보건, 나에게는 휴식이 필요해요.
generatedExamples.english: Regardless of whether I listen to music or watch a movie, I need some relaxation.

generatedExamples.korean: 운전하건 대중교통을 이용하건, 제시간에 도착해야 해요.
generatedExamples.english: Regardless of whether I drive or use public transportation, I need to arrive on time.

items.title: 선택을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Expressing choices
items.example: 열심히 준비했건만 결과가 기대에 못 미쳤다.
items.exampleEn: I prepared hard, yet the result fell short of expectations.
items.description: Contrasts effort/expectation with an opposite outcome.
items.tip: Adds a regretful tone; good for reflective or formal narratives.

generatedExamples.korean: 어제 일찍 자고 일어났건만 오늘 하루가 너무 피곤하다.
generatedExamples.english: I went to bed early last night, but today I feel so tired.

generatedExamples.korean: 그 프로젝트에 많은 시간을 투자했건만 결국 실패로 돌아갔다.
generatedExamples.english: I invested a lot of time in that project, but it ended up failing.

generatedExamples.korean: 친구에게 솔직하게 이야기했건만 그가 상처받을 줄은 몰랐다.
generatedExamples.english: I spoke honestly to my friend, but I didn't expect that he would get hurt.

generatedExamples.korean: 매일 운동했건만 체중이 줄지 않았다.
generatedExamples.english: I exercised every day, but my weight didn't decrease.

generatedExamples.korean: 정성껏 만든 요리였건만 아무도 맛있다고 하지 않았다.
generatedExamples.english: It was a dish I made with great care, but no one said it was delicious.

items.title: 선택을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Expressing choices
items.tip: Use this when choosing the "lesser of two evils." Both options are undesirable, but you're picking the one that's slightly better. Often used with 차라리 (rather).
items.exampleEn: Rather than buying it at the market, I’d buy it at the department store even if it’s pricey.
items.description: Choose the lesser of two undesirable options: 'rather than A, (do) B.'

generatedExamples.korean: 일하느니 차라리 집에서 쉬는 게 낫겠다.
generatedExamples.english: Rather than working, it would be better to rest at home.

generatedExamples.korean: 그 사람과 살느니 차라리 혼자 사는 게 더 편해.
generatedExamples.english: Living with that person is less comfortable than living alone.

generatedExamples.korean: 차라리 늦게 가느니 아예 안 가는 게 낫겠어.
generatedExamples.english: Rather than going late, it would be better not to go at all.

generatedExamples.korean: 그 영화 보느니 차라리 책 읽는 게 좋지.
generatedExamples.english: It's better to read a book rather than watching that movie.

generatedExamples.korean: 이 일을 하느니 차라리 다른 프로젝트를 맡고 싶어.
generatedExamples.english: I'd rather take on another project than do this work.

items.title: 인용을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Reporting / quoting
items.example: 그가 온다니까 기다렸는데 결국 안 왔어요.
items.exampleEn: He said he’d come, so I waited, but he didn’t show up.
items.description: Report what someone said; often implies expectation based on it.
items.tip: Can carry a faint 'and yet…' nuance if the outcome differed.

items.title: 인용을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Reporting / quoting
items.exampleEn: I heard you’re moving tomorrow?
items.tip: Softens a question and checks facts without sounding blunt.

items.title: 인용을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Reporting / quoting
items.tip: Used when you do something based on what you heard from others. Shows the reason for your action.
items.exampleEn: I tried it because (they said) it was delicious.

items.title: 인용을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Reporting / quoting
items.tip: Use when the justification comes from an external source (news, teacher, friend).
items.exampleEn: I'm telling you it's not true!
items.description: Cites reported information as the reason or basis for a suggestion, action, or insistence (short for -(느)ㄴ다고 하니까).

items.title: 인용을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Reporting / quoting
items.tip: Polite confirmation; without -요, it is casual.
items.exampleEn: I heard it will rain tomorrow, is that right?
items.description: Confirms information the speaker previously heard from someone else.

items.title: 인용을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Reporting / quoting
items.tip: Used to report what someone else said. -대요 for statements, -래요 for questions/commands.
items.exampleEn: Minsu says he's coming tomorrow.

items.title: 인용을 나타낼 때
items.subtitle: Reporting / quoting
items.example: 기상청에 의하면 내일 눈이 올 거래요.
items.exampleEn: According to the weather agency, it will snow tomorrow.
items.description: Formal source attribution: ‘according to N’. Distinct from N에 의해(서) which marks cause/agent.
items.tip: Use in reports/presentations to give authority to a claim.

items.title: 명사화
items.subtitle: Nominalisation & fact statements
items.exampleEn: We inform you that you have been accepted.
items.description: Formal nominalization often seen in notices and writing.
items.tip: Great for headings, notices, and succinct formal statements.

items.title: 명사화
items.subtitle: Nominalisation & fact statements
items.tip: Turns verbs into nouns. Used for general activities or habits.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 10: Nominalization | ~기, ~는 것, ~음/ㅁ
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: Learning Korean is difficult.

items.title: 명사화
items.subtitle: Nominalisation & fact statements
items.tip: Most common way to nominalize verbs. Can be shortened to -는 거 in casual speech.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 10: Nominalization | ~기, ~는 것, ~음/ㅁ
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: Learning Korean is interesting.

items.title: 명사화
items.subtitle: Nominalisation & fact statements
items.example: 이 문제를 해결하는 데 시간이 많이 걸렸어요.
items.exampleEn: It took a lot of time to solve this problem.
items.description: Nominalizes a clause to indicate purpose/extent/context.
items.tip: Commonly used with 들다/걸리다/필요하다 to express resources.

items.title: 명사화
items.subtitle: Nominalisation & fact statements
items.tip: Formal way to express "from what I see/know." Used in formal speech and writing.
items.exampleEn: As we inform you, the schedule has changed.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Advanced] Dependent Noun 바 vs 것
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 명사화
items.subtitle: Nominalisation & fact statements
items.tip: Formal dependent noun meaning "fact" or "thing." Often used in formal contexts.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Advanced] Dependent Noun 바 vs 것
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: As far as I know...

items.title: 명사화
items.subtitle: Nominalisation & fact statements
items.tip: Common in notices, reports, and concise memos (…함/…임).
items.exampleEn: It is certain that it is his fault.
items.description: Formal nominalizer used in written language to state facts or completed actions; more abstract than -기.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.exampleEn: They said they were helping, but they just got in the way.
items.description: Ironically frames someone’s stated intent vs. poor result.
items.tip: Carries a critical/ironic tone—avoid in delicate contexts.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.tip: Very formal way to express cause. Often used in news, reports, and formal writing.
items.exampleEn: Because of the typhoon, there was significant damage.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.tip: Formal way to express "due to" or "because of." Common in formal speech and writing.
items.exampleEn: Due to the accident, traffic was paralyzed.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.exampleEn: By cooperating, they created synergy.
items.description: Means/measure that achieves a result: 'by V-ing.'
items.tip: Formal, good for reports and process descriptions.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.example: 바쁘기로서니 연락 한 번은 할 수 있잖아요.
items.exampleEn: Busy as you may be, you could at least call once.
items.description: Concedes A but pushes back: 'even if A, still B.'
items.tip: Adds a slightly reproachful tone—use carefully.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.exampleEn: I felt sorry calling at a late hour.
items.tip: Sits between spoken/written styles; keep sentences compact.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.example: 빨리 발견했기에 망정이지 큰일 날 뻔했어요.
items.exampleEn: It’s a good thing we found it early; otherwise it could’ve been serious.
items.tip: Pairs well with 뻔했다 to highlight near-miss scenarios.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.exampleEn: It looked like rain, so I brought an umbrella.
items.tip: Conversational; explains reactive decisions.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.exampleEn: Since you agreed to help, you should fulfill your responsibility.
items.description: Given that A is true, B is expected/justified.
items.tip: Bridges past commitment to present expectation.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.exampleEn: Now that you’ve promised, you must keep it.
items.tip: Great for rules, policies, and principled stances.

items.title: 원인과 이유
items.subtitle: Formal causes
items.example: 아이들이 떠드는 통에 잠을 못 잤어요.
items.tip: Used to express a chaotic or troublesome situation that causes a negative result.
items.exampleEn: Because the kids were noisy, I couldn’t concentrate.
items.description: Chaotic/troublesome cause leading to a negative result.

resources.title: Korean Grammar Intermediate-level (158) V는 통에, V는 바람에

items.title: 가정·양보
items.subtitle: Hypothesis & concession
items.exampleEn: Assuming he comes, we need to prepare.
items.tip: Useful for planning and scenario analysis.

items.title: 가정·양보
items.subtitle: Hypothesis & concession
items.tip: Rhetorical "even if." Often used in questions to suggest the answer is negative.
items.exampleEn: Even with lots of money, would one be happy?

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Intermediate] 리가 없다 "There's no way"
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 가정·양보
items.subtitle: Hypothesis & concession
items.tip: Strong expression meaning "would rather" or "even if it means." Shows extreme determination.
items.exampleEn: I’d rather die than break my promise.

resources.title: 고급 문법 / "-을망정" 문법 배우기 / Learning Korean

items.title: 가정·양보
items.subtitle: Hypothesis & concession
items.tip: Formal way to say "even if." More formal than -더라도.
items.exampleEn: Even if it’s hard, don’t give up.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Advanced] ~더라도 & ~ㄹ지라도 "Even If"
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 가정·양보
items.subtitle: Hypothesis & concession
items.exampleEn: I’ll pretend I didn’t hear it and let it go.
items.description: Treats something as if it (had) happened/not happened.
items.tip: Great for smoothing social interactions.

items.title: 가정·양보
items.subtitle: Hypothesis & concession
items.tip: Used to express "even if" or "even though." Shows concession.
items.exampleEn: Even if it rains, we’ll depart.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Advanced] ~더라도 & ~ㄹ지라도 "Even If"
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 순차 & 기회
items.subtitle: Sequence & "while I'm at it"
items.tip: Used when doing something additional "while you're at it" or taking advantage of an opportunity.
items.exampleEn: While you're going to the mart, buy some milk too.

items.title: 순차 & 기회
items.subtitle: Sequence & "while I'm at it"
items.example: 숙제를 다 하고서야 놀 수 있어요.
items.tip: Emphasizes that something happens only after completing the first action.
items.exampleEn: Only after finishing homework can you play.

items.title: 순차 & 기회
items.subtitle: Sequence & "while I'm at it"
items.tip: Expresses purpose - "in order to" or "for the purpose of."

resources.title: Korean Grammar - How to use 위해 or 위해서

items.exampleEn: I came to Korea in order to learn Korean.

items.title: 순차 & 기회
items.subtitle: Sequence & "while I'm at it"
items.exampleEn: The moment class ended, students headed out.
items.tip: Narrative flourish; emphasizes speed/abruptness.

items.title: 순차 & 기회
items.subtitle: Sequence & "while I'm at it"
items.exampleEn: As soon as he arrived, he called.
items.description: Short for -자마자; tightly links two actions.
items.tip: Good for concise storytelling.

items.title: 조건 & 의존
items.subtitle: Conditions & dependence
items.exampleEn: When I try to speak, I feel like crying.
items.description: When attempting to do A, B (often obstacle/emotion) follows.
items.tip: Adds intimacy to recounting difficult moments.

items.title: 조건 & 의존
items.subtitle: Conditions & dependence
items.tip: Means "it depends on" how you do something. Shows that the result varies based on approach.
items.exampleEn: Success depends on your mindset.

resources.title: Depending on (~에 따라서, 나름, 다르다) | Live Class Abridged
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 조건 & 의존
items.subtitle: Conditions & dependence
items.tip: Means "depends on" or "is up to." Shows dependency on a factor.

resources.title: Lesson 149: To depend on: ~에 달려 있다
Lesson 149: To depend on: ~에 달려 있다

items.exampleEn: The result depends on your effort.

items.title: 조건 & 의존
items.subtitle: Conditions & dependence
items.tip: Means "if you keep doing" something. Shows a continuous action leading to a result.
items.exampleEn: If you keep reading, your understanding deepens.
items.description: Literary: if one keeps doing A, B results.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Advanced] ~다 보면 "If you keep..."
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 조건 & 의존
items.subtitle: Conditions & dependence
items.exampleEn: The result depends on how you prepare.
items.tip: Great for advice and coaching language.

items.title: 조건 & 의존
items.subtitle: Conditions & dependence
items.tip: Means "as long as" or "while." Shows a condition that must be maintained.
items.exampleEn: As long as it’s possible, I’ll do my best.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Advanced] 한 "As long as"
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 따로·같이
items.subtitle: Listing hectic actions
items.tip: Lists multiple actions that make someone busy or overwhelmed. Shows hectic situations.

resources.title: Live Korean Class [Advanced] "About to" ~락 말락 하다 & ~랑 말랑 하다
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: I'm busy cleaning and cooking (and everything else).

items.title: 따로·같이
items.subtitle: Listing hectic actions
items.tip: Lists items or actions inclusively. Similar to "including" or "such as."
items.exampleEn: Take everything - books, pens, and all.

items.title: 따로·같이
items.subtitle: Listing hectic actions
items.example: 은행 가는 김에 우편도 보내 주세요.
items.exampleEn: Since you’re going to the bank, please mail this too.
items.description: ‘While at it’; piggyback a task on another.
items.tip: Natural in daily planning; don’t overuse in formal writing.

items.title: 따로·같이
items.subtitle: Listing hectic actions
items.exampleEn: Contact me as soon as you arrive.
items.description: ‘As soon as’ / ‘just as’ depending on context.
items.tip: For 'immediately when', use with action verbs in present/future.

items.title: 대조
items.subtitle: Contrast
items.exampleEn: Rather than feeling good, I feel at ease.
items.description: Refines or corrects a label: ‘not so much A as B’; polite way to offer a more accurate characterization.
items.tip: Avoid direct antonyms (e.g., 어렵다기보다는 쉽다). Offer a more precise alternative instead.

items.title: 대조
items.subtitle: Contrast
items.example: 형은 키가 큰 반면에 동생은 작아요.
items.tip: Used to show contrast between two things. Means "on the other hand" or "whereas."

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 116: 반면에 "On the Other Hand"
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: While the older brother is tall, the younger one is short.

items.title: 대조
items.subtitle: Contrast
items.exampleEn: Despite the high cost, we signed the contract.
items.tip: Suited for reports, essays, and business contexts.

items.title: 대조
items.subtitle: Contrast
items.exampleEn: Even though I did my best, I failed the exam.
items.description: Literary concessive connector conveying frustrated expectation or regret; stronger than -지만.
items.tip: Suited to literary/formal tones; rare in casual conversation.

items.title: 대조
items.subtitle: Contrast
items.exampleEn: Even after apologizing, I wasn’t forgiven.
items.tip: Good for surprising or disappointing outcomes.

items.title: 대조
items.subtitle: Contrast
items.tip: Means "instead of" or "in place of." Shows substitution or alternative choice.
items.exampleEn: I'll pay by card instead of cash.

items.title: 유사
items.subtitle: Similarity & virtuality
items.tip: Means "practically" or "as good as." Shows that something is virtually the case.
items.exampleEn: It's as good as finished already.

items.title: 유사
items.subtitle: Similarity & virtuality
items.tip: Means "whether or not" with the implication that it doesn't matter.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 113: (으)나 마나 and 봤자 "No Matter"
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: There's no point in saying it, so it's the same whether you say it or not.

items.title: 유사
items.subtitle: Similarity & virtuality
items.tip: Often used to criticize or emphasize equivalence to an undesirable act.
items.exampleEn: That's no different from lying.
items.description: Means 'no different from' / 'practically the same as.'

items.title: 유사
items.subtitle: Similarity & virtuality
items.exampleEn: I worked almost day and night.
items.tip: Conveys strong effort or near-total extent.

items.title: 유사
items.subtitle: Similarity & virtuality
items.exampleEn: It felt familiar, as if I’d seen it in a dream.
items.tip: Nice for expressive descriptions and narratives.

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.exampleEn: He’s not only diligent but also highly capable.
items.tip: More neutral than -기는커녕; good in endorsements.

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.tip: Sounds bookish/formal; great for essays, reviews, or newsy tones.

resources.title: 거니와 "Not only" | Live Class Abridged
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: Not only is it expensive, it also tastes bad.
items.description: Formal ‘not only…but also,’ frequently adding negative info.

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.exampleEn: Far from helping, they only got in the way.
items.tip: Emphatic; avoid overuse to keep tone balanced.

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.tip: Sounds a bit evaluative/critical; often contrasts a fancy option with a simpler one.
items.exampleEn: This food is worse than just having ramen.
items.description: ‘Not as good as doing A’ (doing B would be worse than A).

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.exampleEn: I’ll allow it, but with conditions.
items.tip: Feels legalistic/official—fits rules and clauses.

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.example: 한국어는 물론이고 중국어도 할 수 있어요.
items.tip: Common in spoken and written Korean; pairs naturally with 도 to add the extra item.

resources.title: GU5.6 ~은/는 물론이고 (not to mention, to say nothing of)

items.exampleEn: Not only Korean, I can also speak Chinese.
items.description: ‘Not to mention…’ / ‘in addition to…’ to stack a stronger item after a given item.

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.tip: Means "even" with emphasis. -조차 is more formal, -마저 more emotional.
items.exampleEn: Even my family didn’t believe me.

resources.title: 도, 까지, 마저, 조차 "Even" | Live Class Abridged
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.exampleEn: Even my family didn’t believe me.
items.tip: Heightens drama; use to mark final straw or surprise.

items.title: 추가·포함
items.subtitle: Addition & inclusion
items.example: 서울을 비롯해서 전국 곳곳에 분점이 있다.
items.exampleEn: There are branches nationwide, starting with Seoul.
items.tip: Great for spotlighting a key example among many.

items.title: 습관 & 태도
items.subtitle: Habits & tendencies
items.example: 어릴 때 자주 놀러 가곤 했어요.
items.tip: You’ll see it with time phrases (옛날에, 예전에) or frequency adverbs (자주).

resources.title: TOPIK II 문법 수업 (6): [ 곤하다, 기 일쑤이다, -아/어 대다 ]

items.exampleEn: When I was young, I used to go out and play often.
items.description: Marks a past habit or repeated action (similar to ‘used to’).

items.title: 습관 & 태도
items.subtitle: Habits & tendencies
items.tip: Means "it's common for" or "tends to." Shows frequent occurrence of undesirable things.
items.exampleEn: He’s habitually late to appointments.

resources.title: TOPIK II 문법 수업 (6) : [ 곤하다, 기 일쑤이다, 아 대다 ]

items.title: 습관 & 태도
items.subtitle: Habits & tendencies
items.example: 밥은 먹는 둥 마는 둥 했어.
items.exampleEn: I barely ate at all.
items.tip: Colloquial; conveys dissatisfaction with the effort.

resources.title: HowToStudyKorean: -는 둥 마는 둥 하다 검색

items.title: 습관 & 태도
items.subtitle: Habits & tendencies
items.tip: Shows continuous or repeated action, often with negative connotation.
items.exampleEn: These days, he keeps grumbling.

resources.title: ~대다 Habits | Live Class Abridged
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 정도·강조
items.subtitle: Degree & emphasis
items.tip: Frequent in speeches or formal writing; set phrase: 감사할 따름입니다.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 127: 뿐이다 & 따름이다 “Only”
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: I’m simply grateful.

items.title: 정도·강조
items.subtitle: Degree & emphasis
items.exampleEn: My stomach was about to burst (that full).
items.tip: Vivid exaggeration—use for color in narratives.

items.title: 정도·강조
items.subtitle: Degree & emphasis
items.tip: Common with adjectives like 기쁘다/만족스럽다/불편하다 + 기가 이를 데 없다.

resources.title: A-기(가) 이를 데 없다 Korean grammar

items.exampleEn: I’m extremely happy (couldn’t be happier).
items.description: ‘To the utmost degree’ for strong praise/complaint about a state.

items.title: 정도·강조
items.subtitle: Degree & emphasis
items.exampleEn: I waited and waited, then finally left.
items.description: So much that it crosses a threshold.
items.tip: Implies buildup → breaking point.

items.title: 정도·강조
items.subtitle: Degree & emphasis
items.tip: Translate to a natural intensifier in English (‘pretty’, ‘quite’, ‘really’) not literally ‘not easy’.
items.exampleEn: It’s quite (really) difficult.

items.title: 의도
items.subtitle: Intentions & plans
items.exampleEn: I intended to help, but it ended up getting in the way.
items.tip: Explains mishaps without sounding defensive.

items.title: 의도
items.subtitle: Intentions & plans
items.tip: Close to ‘I fully intend to…’—use for decisive plans or resolutions.
items.exampleEn: This time, I’m determined to succeed.

items.title: 의도
items.subtitle: Intentions & plans
items.exampleEn: He keeps trying to interfere, and it’s uncomfortable.
items.tip: Useful for boundaries and complaints.

items.title: 의도
items.subtitle: Intentions & plans
items.exampleEn: I was about to go out, but it rained so I gave up.
items.description: About to do A, but B happened and stopped it.
items.tip: Great for 'almost did' narratives.

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.exampleEn: He nodded as if to say it’s okay.
items.description: Non-verbal sign implying a quoted message.
items.tip: Pairs with gestures (끄덕이다, 미소 짓다).

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.exampleEn: It’s bound to be heavy traffic.
items.tip: Use for 'called it' moments—don’t overdo negativity.

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.tip: Expresses impossibility or disbelief. Means "there's no way" or "impossible."
items.exampleEn: There’s no way that’s true.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Intermediate] 리가 없다 "There's no way"
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.tip: Expresses likelihood or probability. Means "it's likely" or "it's probable."
items.exampleEn: That sounds plausible.

resources.title: Live Korean Class [Advanced] ~법하다 "Likely..."
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.tip: Contrast with 지 못하다 (skill/ability) vs (으)ㄹ 수 없다 (circumstance/possibility).
items.exampleEn: I can’t believe it.
items.description: Emphatic inability/impossibility (with the focus on circumstances).

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.tip: Often paired with 그래서/결국 to explain why something was inevitable.
items.exampleEn: There’s no choice but to do it this way.

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.exampleEn: If you overdo it, you’re likely to get hurt.
items.description: Tends to / is prone to happen.
items.tip: Useful for warnings and common-sense advice.

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.exampleEn: He smiled as if nothing had happened.
items.description: ‘As if’; describes manner resembling a state.
items.tip: Nice for body-language descriptions.

items.title: 추측·가능성
items.subtitle: Guess & probability
items.exampleEn: He seems tired.
items.tip: Softer than 단정; polite inferences.

items.title: 제외
items.subtitle: Exclusion
items.exampleEn: People are bound to make mistakes.
items.tip: Gentle reassurance in feedback/coaching.

items.title: 제외
items.subtitle: Exclusion
items.exampleEn: When you put in effort, you naturally feel rewarded.
items.tip: Sounds proverbial—great for conclusions.

items.title: 제외
items.subtitle: Exclusion
items.tip: Often used with negative predicates (모르다/없다/못하다).

resources.title: HOW TO USE 말고 IN KOREAN SENTENCE

items.exampleEn: No one but you knows.
items.description: ‘Except for / other than’—excludes all but the specified noun.

items.title: 제외
items.subtitle: Exclusion
items.tip: Often pairs with 불가능하다/어렵다/안 된다 to stress indispensability.

resources.title: Lesson 74: (topic on ‘regardless of’ / contrastive forms; use as a fallback reading)
Lesson 74: It doesn't matter/ Regardless of (상관없다/상관없이)

items.exampleEn: Without your help, it’s impossible.
items.description: ‘Without X’ with emphasis on necessity of X.

items.title: 제외
items.subtitle: Exclusion
items.tip: Slightly more formal than 말고는; reads more written/polite.
items.exampleEn: Other than this, there’s no other way.

items.title: 비교
items.subtitle: Comparison
items.exampleEn: I was busy all day cleaning and cooking.
items.description: Busy with A and B (hectic listing).
items.tip: Evokes bustle—nice in story openings.

items.title: 비교
items.subtitle: Comparison
items.exampleEn: You keep going on about whether to go or not.
items.tip: Often carries a slightly exasperated tone.

items.title: 비교
items.subtitle: Comparison
items.exampleEn: Some say it’s hard, while others say it’s fun.
items.tip: Balances two sides of an argument.

items.title: 비교
items.subtitle: Comparison
items.tip: Politer/softer than saying something is ‘bad’ outright.
items.exampleEn: This movie isn’t as good as the previous one.

items.title: 비교
items.subtitle: Comparison
items.tip: 시험 볼 만하다 / 가 볼 만하다 are common ‘recommendation’ patterns.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 78: "Worth Doing" | 만하다
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: This job is doable / worth doing.
items.description: Assesses adequacy or worth doing of an action/state.

items.title: 비교
items.subtitle: Comparison
items.tip: You can flip to 에 비해(서) in casual writing; both are fine.
items.exampleEn: Compared to last year, it has improved a lot.

items.title: 비교
items.subtitle: Comparison
items.exampleEn: Bring everything—books, notebooks, and all.
items.tip: Good for casual lists; keep items concrete.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.exampleEn: After long discussions, they reached an agreement.
items.tip: Pairs well with nouns like 노력/논의/고민.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.exampleEn: I was so tired that I couldn’t even respond.
items.tip: Use with emotions/conditions (기쁜/슬픈/화난).

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.tip: Two core senses: immediacy (오자마자) and ‘the way’ (말하는 대로).

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Intermediate] "As soon as" 대로
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: Contact me as soon as you arrive.
items.description: ‘As soon as / just as’—immediate sequence or ‘the way (someone does)’.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.tip: Pairs naturally with 만큼…-다 structure for comparisons.

resources.title: Live Korean Class [Intermediate] ~만큼 “As Much As” & “Because”
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: You’ll get results in proportion to how much you work.
items.description: ‘As much as / to the extent that’—proportional relationship.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.tip: Narrative/explanatory; great in personal stories and reflections.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Advanced] ~다 보니까 “Realizing”
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: As I kept studying, my skills improved.
items.description: After doing something for a while, you realize/arrive at a result.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.tip: Follow it with a 2nd action that cuts in (잠들다/넘어지다/떨어뜨리다).

resources.title: Live Korean Class | While (면서, 동안, 다가)
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: I fell asleep while studying.
items.description: Shows interruption/change while doing an action.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.tip: Common in advice/warnings: 그렇게 먹다가는~, 그렇게 늦잠 자다가는~.

resources.title: 다가는 Continuing Actions | Live Class Abridged
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: If you keep doing it like this, you’ll fail.
items.description: Warns that continuing the current action will lead to a bad result.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.tip: Usually the subject is 3rd-person or someone other than the speaker for A.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 72: 더니
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: He was sick, and in the end he went to the hospital.
items.description: Speaker’s observation of A followed by a related outcome B.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.exampleEn: It turned out harder than I thought.
items.tip: Conversational—keeps tone friendly and light.

items.title: 시간 표현
items.subtitle: Time expressions
items.exampleEn: I finally pulled it off.
items.tip: Adds triumph; great for motivational contexts.

items.title: 원인 표현
items.subtitle: Cause expressions
items.exampleEn: Preferences change according to age.
items.tip: Common in surveys, reports, and analyses.

items.title: 원인 표현
items.subtitle: Cause expressions
items.exampleEn: I presented while many people were watching.
items.tip: Useful for formal event descriptions.

items.title: 원인 표현
items.subtitle: Cause expressions
items.tip: Formal way to express reason or cause. Often used in written Korean.

resources.title: Lesson 147: ~는 바람에 – A negative result occurred because of an action
Lesson 147: ~는 바람에 – A negative result occurred because of an action

items.exampleEn: For that reason, I changed my decision.

items.title: 원인 표현
items.subtitle: Cause expressions
items.example: 다 끝난 마당에 이제 와서 왜 그래?
items.exampleEn: Now that it’s all over, why bring it up?
items.description: Highlights a (late) stage that makes the point stronger.
items.tip: Often rhetorical and slightly scolding.

items.title: 원인 표현
items.subtitle: Cause expressions
items.tip: Natural with weather/accidents/outside conditions; tone is a bit apologetic/explanatory.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Intermediate] ~는 바람에 “Because of”
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: Because it rained, the picnic was canceled.
items.description: Uncontrollable external cause leading to a negative result.

items.title: 원인 표현
items.subtitle: Cause expressions
items.tip: Use carefully in sensitive contexts—sounds like you’re attributing fault.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | “Because of” 탓에
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: I was late because of the traffic jam.
items.description: Cause with a subtle sense of blame/responsibility (more formal than 바람에).

items.title: 원인 표현
items.subtitle: Cause expressions
items.exampleEn: For a beginner, your pronunciation is quite good.
items.tip: Nice for compliments with context.

items.title: 정도 표현
items.subtitle: Degree expressions
items.tip: Emphasizes extreme degree. Stronger than just -는 정도.

resources.title: (으)ㄹ 정도로 and -(으)ㄹ 정도이다 grammar = to the extent that
(으)ㄹ 정도로 and -(으)ㄹ 정도이다 grammar = to the extent that

items.exampleEn: I was so sick I thought I would die.

items.title: 정도 표현
items.subtitle: Degree expressions
items.exampleEn: Even if I wanted to believe it, I can’t.
items.tip: Good for expressing constraints beyond one’s control.

items.title: 정도 표현
items.subtitle: Degree expressions
items.exampleEn: I was extremely satisfied.
items.tip: Perfect for polished reviews and speeches.

items.title: 정도 표현
items.subtitle: Degree expressions
items.tip: Shows degree or extent. Means "to the extent that" or "so much that."

resources.title: (으)ㄹ 정도로 and -(으)ㄹ 정도이다 grammar = to the extent that
(으)ㄹ 정도로 and -(으)ㄹ 정도이다 grammar = to the extent that

items.exampleEn: I was moved to the point of tears.

items.title: 정도 표현
items.subtitle: Degree expressions
items.tip: Shows cause and effect. Basic way to express "so... that" or "because."

resources.title: How to Say "Because" Using Arthur/Eoseo - Korean Grammar

items.exampleEn: It's so cold that I can't go out.

items.title: 정도 표현
items.subtitle: Degree expressions
items.exampleEn: It was extremely (by no means easy).
items.description: Idiomatic double negative for strong emphasis.
items.tip: Sounds formal/stylistic; great for emphasis in writing.

items.title: 상황 표현
items.subtitle: Situation expressions
items.tip: Formal expression meaning "while" or "among." Often used in formal contexts.

resources.title: Live Korean Class [Advanced] "While" 가운데
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: I gave a speech while many people were watching.

items.title: 상황 표현
items.subtitle: Situation expressions
items.tip: Means "in the middle of" with emphasis on interruption or specific moment.
items.exampleEn: A phone call came during the meeting.

items.title: 상황 표현
items.subtitle: Situation expressions
items.tip: Means "while" or "during." Shows time period when something happens.

resources.title: Korean Grammar - 는 동안에 during / while

items.exampleEn: I went traveling during vacation.

items.title: 상황 표현
items.subtitle: Situation expressions
items.tip: Shows ongoing action. Means "in the middle of" or "currently doing."

resources.title: In the middle (中) 중 & 중이다 (한자) | Korean FAQ
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: I'm studying right now.

items.title: 상황 표현
items.subtitle: Situation expressions
items.exampleEn: Do it that way (semi-formal directive).
items.description: Older/formal style, senior-to-junior or in literature.
items.tip: Shows hierarchy; sounds old-fashioned in modern settings.

items.title: 상황 표현
items.subtitle: Situation expressions
items.exampleEn: Do so (old/formal tone).
items.tip: Use in historical/literary contexts; avoid in daily speech.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.exampleEn: It helps, but there are limits.
items.tip: Smoother than 하지만 in formal writing.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.exampleEn: There’s no way that could happen.
items.tip: Emphatic; keep for decisive rebuttals.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.exampleEn: I hurried for fear of being late.
items.tip: Elevated tone; pairs with 걱정/염려 contexts.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.exampleEn: The price is low, and the quality is good.
items.tip: Great for specs, brochures, and resumes.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.exampleEn: Since there’s no time, let’s do it next time.
items.tip: Solid for reports and official notices.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.tip: Shows sequence - "after doing" something. Emphasizes completion before next action.
items.exampleEn: I played after doing my homework.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.tip: Means "on the way" to somewhere. Shows doing something while going somewhere.

resources.title: 길에 "On the Way" | Live Class Abridged
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

items.exampleEn: I stopped by the mart on my way home.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.exampleEn: He acted as if he didn’t know.
items.description: Pretending/acting as though a state is true.
items.tip: Conveys subtle sarcasm or indirect criticism.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.tip: Means "while at it" or "taking the opportunity." Similar to 김에 but more formal.

resources.title: Lesson 156: ~(으)려는 참 and ~(으)려던 참 – One was just about to
Lesson 156: ~(으)려는 참 and ~(으)려던 참 – One was just about to

items.exampleEn: While I was cleaning, I also organized things.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.exampleEn: While conducting research, we also carried out teaching.
items.tip: Use in project write-ups and CVs.

items.title: 기타 고급 표현
items.subtitle: Other advanced expressions
items.exampleEn: The door was closed / (I) made someone close the door.
items.description: Passive vs. causative voice formation and usage.
items.tip: Teach side-by-side to contrast subject roles clearly.
